instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.PLT_RESET: What is PLT_RESET? PLT_RESET stands for platform reset. When this is asserted the machine will not POST. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
Board arrived without turning on. I found oxidation in the oxidation on <RESISTOR>R1663</RESISTOR>/62/66/26. I replaced them all and it didn't work. Checking the voltages, I noticed problems with the SMC. Replaced it and the mac turned on, worked perfect for two days and stopped.

SMC bypass did not work.

PPBus is 8.6v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> - 0v

Will there be a problem with the SMC again?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
This signal switches between 1 and 0, depending the power state; check the table from page 59.

Are you using original Magsafe 2 charger?
Do you get amber light?
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
I was on vacation and came back today, the Mac is working. I'll keep testing and hope to stop again, to check the lines.

I had the original MagSafe 2. With amber light.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
After a week of running, the Mac stopped.

I don't have <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
I don't have the <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, it's impossible to have the _SUS!

I didn't find any other components damaged or shorted.

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> - 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
What is actual <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?

Post <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> basic voltages: 23, 22, 12, 13, 29, 21.
Check diode mode to ground at L7520/60.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
23 - 8.6v
22 - 3.3v
12 - 3.3v
13 - 1.9v (strange)
29 - 5v
21 - 3.3

Diodo mode
L7520 - both pins 0.450
L7560 - both pins 0.360

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
Because of pin 13, I analyzed the area near <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.

The <RESISTOR>R7539</RESISTOR> was altered on the board, outside the board measuring 20k. I compared it in diode mode with another board, pin 1 on the <RESISTOR>R7539</RESISTOR> was 0.500 and on the good board it was 0.740. I changed the <CAPACITOR>C7539</CAPACITOR> and now I have 20k on the <RESISTOR>R7539</RESISTOR>. The board turned on, but pin 13 of the <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is still 1.9v.

Now it's time to test! If it turned on because of the heat or if that was the problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
Why strange 1.9V???
Not good enough for 2V reference voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message:
Reading quickly, I got confused with the 3v one.

But it brought me to the issue of the resistor. Could this be the problem? The Mac continues to work.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
threads.message: All resistors in that area are critical...
